newsitem.title: ITALY: San Paolo share offer confounds doubters.
newsitem.headline: San Paolo share offer confounds doubters.

text.p: San Paolo's successful share offering illustrates there is good interest in Italian banking stock when management makes a good presentation and promises an improving trend in results, analysts said on Monday.

Italy's biggest bank completed its week-long share offering last Friday with an offer price fixed higher than many analysts had forecast given the poor past performance of Italy's banking sector with a surprising strong level of investor interest.

San Paolo di Torino announced on Saturday the final price to the public of its share offer would be a 2.5 percent discount to Friday's closing share price at 10,435 lire ($6.26) a share while for institutional investors the price would be 10,630 lire.
Many analysts had expected price to be a critical element in the offer, and had suggested that it needed to be close to 10,000 lire a share to attract strong investor demand.

But good presentations from San Paolo, improvements it has made over the last 18 months and promises of more to come convinced many investors that this was a stock with plenty of potential for the future as Italy's banking sector restructures.

"The price was certainly better than expected at the beginning of the week with investors impressed by the objectives that the management had set," said Marco Nascimbeni, Italian equity specialist at Merrill Lynch in Milan.

But others thought the shares were good value, and now the bank was in effect fully privatised the management could continue to make changes and transform itself into a banking group in the northern European model.
"At the end of the day, the price represents good value and the big positive is that San Paolo is now finally privatised," said banking analyst Francesco Ricciulli at brokers Pasfin.
The share prices reacted favourable on Monday rising 0.82 percent to 10,790 lire despite a lower overall Milan market.

San Paolo's global offer was for 220 million shares, or a 26.96 percent stake, sold by the bank's controlling foundation bringing its own stake below 20 percent. The share issue raised around 2.3 trillion lire.
A green shoe over-allotment of 33 million extra shares is now likely to be triggered with the offer more than three times oversubscribed with demand seen for around 760 million lire.
But the success is not likely to lead to an avalanche of new share issues in the banking sector with prime privatisation candidate, Italy's largest savings bank Cariplo, now a talks with Ambroveneto.
